subject: Design: VMI certificate exchange Interface
commitMessage:
Design: VMI certificate exchange Interface

This commit describes the BMC interface which
allows certificate exchange between HMC and VMI.

Signed-off-by: Ravi Teja <raviteja28031990@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I7f0185f3080fc28be691b428934a6bcf7daaf0c7

comments.message:
Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

In general, if reviewers have asked questions about your document it means that the text is not clear enough. The way to resolve the comments is to update the document to clarify the text in _addition_ to replying to the comments themselves.

Patch Set 15: Code-Review-1

I have issues recorded in comments on PS14 that are not resolved.

Removed reviewer Andrew Jeffery with the following votes:

* Code-Review-1 by Andrew Jeffery <andrew@aj.id.au>

Patch Set 25:

@Ravi/@Ratan - any updates on this? I'm interested because once we move to a D-Bus based API, that will have some PLDM impact as well.

Patch Set 26:

> Patch Set 25:
> 
> @Ravi/@Ratan - any updates on this? I'm interested because once we move to a D-Bus based API, that will have some PLDM impact as well.

updated design for including dbus approach

Patch Set 29:

Can we find an appropriate set of domain experts to give feedback on this one?

Patch Set 29:

> Patch Set 29:
> 
> Can we find an appropriate set of domain experts to give feedback on this one?

Requesting Gunnar, Brad/Adriana to review.

Patch Set 29:

> Patch Set 29:
> 
> > Patch Set 29:
> > 
> > Can we find an appropriate set of domain experts to give feedback on this one?
> 
> Requesting Gunnar, Brad/Adriana to review.

Not a domain expert here. 
I'll leave to someone else.

Patch Set 29: Code-Review+1

This accurately describes the high level design
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 88b4151b816c1e9ee73326b6088588088ddc7c9f by Patrick Williams
Please remove references to internal ibm links.

It's hard for someone outside IBM to understand this document with the use of terms like PHYP and VMI. I see there are some other design docs related to the BMC - management console area. It seems like there needs to be a master design doc describing IBM requirements, and this one needs to to point to that document, and based on that, you can decide how much more details needs to be added to this document.
sure Deepak, Good point,We will upload the requirement doc also.
+1. If we do use terms like PHYP and VMI we should explain them.
Please be sure lines wrap at 80 chars

This to me implies direct HMC to VMI communication but the BMC does some intermediate work I think? It process's the REST command, creates private key and certificate file, and forwards up to VMI for signing? So maybe a arrow to BMC, show what it does, show it call VMI, then show that going back to BMC and then finally BMC responding to HMC?

BMC receives certificate signing request from HMC through REST command and  forwards certificate signing request to host via pldm call.
done
Add the results of your findings. Does an infrastructure already exist, can it be extended, what are the advantages/disadvantages?

yes,we have certificate manager infrastructure for BMC
I have captured my finding below
What are the impacted repos that would need to make changes to make use of this new object?
we will be creating dbus method, management console will be using this method
IBM specific acronyms have been used. Can we fix that?

Is this a problem specific to phyp? I'm wondering if we're better off either a) making this problem description more general, or if that can't be done, then b) moving this to a docs directory in the meta-ibm repo.
Hang on, where's the discussion about whether a) could be done before resorting to b)? Throwing it in the too-hard basket isn't okay.
It has been discussed and decided in design meetings to push HMC-BMC Designs in meta-ibm,as these are IBM specific requirements

You're contributing to an open source project. You should be having discussions that affect the project in the open as well. Making decisions in internal meetings doesn't help anyone's cause.

At the very least you need to *document* any decisions made in these internal discussions so others who did not participate can have some understanding. But I strongly discourage dealing with these issues internally to start with.
Why must this go through the BMC? The previous step is VMI network config, so post that why can't the HMC use existing internal inband authentication mechanisms?

Deepak, There is not an internal authentication mechanism in PHYP/VMI.

this certificate exchange will allow the HMC to get its client certificate which is signed by the VMI and with this certificate HMC will connect to the VMI.

HMC has two connections
1) HMC-BMC (SSL followed by the authentication)
2) HMC-VMI (client certificate-based authentication)
We'd like to use standard PLDM commands (BIOS attributes), that could mean the response comes back asynchronously.

Yes, but that would impact pldm,The flow would be same.
HTTP time out is greater than PLDM.
Why can't this use a Redfish API?
We don't have the redfish API for the same.

Ravi, I want you to put the alternatives here.

Like how can PHYP/VMI use the BMC authentication module through PLDM to avoid the client certificate exchange?
IBM specific acronyms have been used here and in the doc. Can you fix that?

What PLDM command do you propose to use here?

I'm not in favor of inventing OEM PLDM commands throughout the stack before an investigation happens on how standard PLDM can be used.

As discussed, proposals here 
1. Define BIOS attribute with string type as CSR is string.
2. We can use SPDM GET_CERTIFICATE,but i think its deferred beyond P10 due to its impact.
How does this design compare to the proposed one? I know we've spoken about pros and cons of both in workshops but they haven't been captured in this document.
Ravi, you need to write the pro and cons for this approach.
this design is ruled out anyway.
Ravi, Is it the authenticate call where VMI can use the authentication module of BMC through some PLDm message.
Bullet not needed here since there is only 1 line
What happens when the same HMC creates another session ? Is there a GET command to get the already signed certificate?

No.we dont store signed certificate returned by VMI.
once HMC gets Signed certificate that can be used across sessions.
no need to mention its curl command.
Is this an encrypted certificate string?
Is this an encrypted certificate string ?
I dont think this much details of explaining what is CSR etc is needed in this document
ok.i think its better to explain as we are discussing CSR based certificates
Is this note is an alternative considered ?
yes.notes to says why we are not using existing certificate manager

I think there's a lot of IBM-specific context missing from this problem description. Please keep in mind you're contributing this to an open-source community that supports platforms made by companies other than IBM.
+1, for example you haven't described why the BMC is needed for this exchange.
Done. updated why BMC needs to do certificate exchange and updated Background section with more details.
Do you need to refer to another doc here?

I dont think we need point to any doc.
Added little more background for this design here

Some more details are needed I think :

- How does HMC know when to send the signCSR request?
- How should the BMC respond when VMI is not up?
- What kind of errors are expected and how are they handled?

HMC can connect and send request once bmc reaches standby/ready state.
yes we will consider all possible errors like vmi is not up or sign CSR failures.
we wanted map to PLDM command errors, will be decided during pldm command implementation.
we will update this document once we complete pldm command implementation

Errors provided by the public interface need to be defined at the time that the public API is designed. Errors are a fundamental part of API design. We can't delay their definition until later.

It's fine to be *wrong* about the errors and need to fix them up before this goes into production, but you can't just punt on that aspect of the API design.
I would expect details in the document. In your gerrit response comment, I'm ok if you just say done :)
Details need to be documented in this design. Basically if someone looks at this doc and wants to implement the PLDM part - they don't know now what command to implement.

We have not decided which pldm command to use yet, created github issue for the same
https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/1271
Can we propose something in the design. I'm a bit concerned just leaving this to the implementer.

But how are you planning to do this? Manually? Automated? What about testing failure cases? Testing the happy case isn't enough. What about certificate expiry, revocation, incorrect date/time issues, incorrect certificates etc?

yes, we test this manually once we develop this feature,
if there are issues like certificate expiry, revocation, incorrect date/time issues, incorrect certificates, then management console fails to establish connection to VMI.
Then hmc needs to run signCSR again to initiate certificate exchange.
bmc does not store/generate any certificate, this interface just allows certificate exchange between VMI and HMC.
we will update all error cases once we decide on pldm command.

> yes, we test this manually once we develop this feature,

Manual testing means it will be broken.

Please consider adding tests to openbmc-test-automation given it's an integration test.

> if there are issues like certificate expiry, revocation, incorrect date/time issues, incorrect certificates, then management console fails to establish connection to VMI.

Right, so that's a host firmware test, no worries.

> we will update all error cases once we decide on pldm command.

Please see my comment above about errors in the context of API design.

It's still not clear from the opening sentence that this is specific to enterprise POWER machines. Please make the context clear. To make this clear, OpenBMC also supports x86-64 and ARM hosts, it is not POWER-specific.

We can specify that IBM systems may have the IBM specific host-firmware(PHYP) and the KVM and this API would be used only for the PHYP based machine.
Enable/disable of this API would be controlled by the build time configure variable.
This is the first time anyone reading this document gets a hint that you're not solving a generic problem but rather one specific to IBM enterprise-class POWER machines.

This isn't a proper impact analysis. What are the negative components of your design? How do they impact CPU/RAM/flash? How do they impact the system design in terms of integration? How do they impact the security of the BMC? Are we parsing the certificates on the BMC at all?

What other problems might there be? Please explore them in this section.
Please expand this as per the discussion on PS11.

This interface perspective the HTTP error code could be 4XX/5XX.
But it would be mapped depending on the PLDM error response.
PLDM has to throw error in the following scenario
-> PHYP is not up.
-> PHYP throws error for certificate validation which in turn comes to PLDM and PLDM gives it to web server
   Which webserver will map it to 4xx/5xx depends on the error.
Regarding testing of this interface you can verify that the string which was sent by the client has been correctly received by the web server
If PLDM throws an error send the error response, for now you can map to Internal server Error(500).
Do not use acronyms before introducing the expansion.

Do not use acronyms before introducing the expansion.

Separately, are HMCs widely used for managing x86 and ARM machines? If they're POWER specific then you need to open the problem description with this fact so that anyone not interested in POWER can disregard it without having to read the whole thing.
in problem description, we mentioned VMI and HMC which are POWER specific

There's no way for people to know that they are being used in a POWER context. You're leaving people guessing, which is not the point of documentation. Please expand the problem description to provide context.

You seem to have a pattern of not separating parenthesised comments with a space before the opening parenthesis. This should be "Host firmware (PHYP)". Please audit the rest of the document for these issues.
What PLDM error responses are possible? How will they be mapped to 4XX/5XX codes?
As part of webserver code we catch pldm error and maps to appropriate HTTP codes
By "how" I was referring to "What criteria do you have for mapping PLDM error code X to HTTP error code Y", not how/where you would code the translation.
Andrew, PLDM API investigation has not been done yet, Ravi would be working on it. and the HTTP error codes would be mapped depending on the PLDM error code.

I am working on PLDM API investigation story
https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/1284
Are we mapping all PLDM error responses to an HTTP 500?

Ravi, it could be 4XX/5XX?
4XX: user provided invalid data(invalid key size/certificate expiry date etc).
5xx: PHYP throws some error which is not specific to certificate data but some thing else.
      or
      There is some error in BMC during this cmd processing.

Why hasn't this been done? I think this document should link to the relevant PLDM proposal, or define the relevant PLDM commands itself. Otherwise, how do we know that we're not making mistakes with the external interface if we haven't thought through how this might be implemented at the PLDM layer?
as mentioned earlier,there is pldm issue opened for the same.
Please reference the PLDM proposal here then, and add me as a reviewer to the PLDM proposal.

> Why hasn't this been done? I think this document should link to the relevant PLDM proposal, or define the relevant PLDM commands itself. Otherwise, how do we know that we're not making mistakes with the external interface if we haven't thought through how this might be implemented at the PLDM layer?

This is exactly my concern. At the moment we're presuming that the out of band API proposed here will not be impacted by the inband PLDM API. It will be worthwhile to spend effort on what the PLDM commands should be as part of this design doc - I don't see this as an external interface design only. Ravi - I've spoken to Ratan about this and I can help facilitate the PLDM discussion, for eg with the host firmware tram. Let me know if you need me to do that.
i am working on PLDM proposal, will update
Can you please unpack this and explain why security isn't impacted? Code needs to be written, all code has bugs, and the code is probably C++ and so there are opportunities for memory corruption.

i mean to say that HMC and BMC connected via secured connection.
and this api would be used by HMC over secure connection
That's missing the point of what I'm asking for though. Please think about how the code you're adding might add to the attack surface area of the BMC.

I think this should mention openbmc-test-automation: Either you need to say that's where the tests will be implemented, or make some argument against implementing the tests there. Either way it involves writing its name down.

this section, covers how to test this API.
i think openbmc-test-automation would be covered in test case design doc

They are not separate problems. Please stop trying to split them. The point of writing these documents is to think about the problem holistically to make sure we're getting the interfaces right. Trying to disregard issues like this means we will likely wind up with a poor interface or implementation.

As part of testing this interface, Client will send some string(CSR) and as a response client will get some string(Certificate).
So check that the given certificate is valid and it is wrt to the CSR given.
Yes but how are you going to do that?
as mentioned above,will verify if management console able to establish secure connection to VMI with this certificate
Can we enumerate what might cause the certificate to be considered invalid and how these conditions impact the error codes returned to the user?
Andrew, My expectation is from the PHYP/VMI is that they would be giving a different error for Invalid Certificate Data v/s some other PHYP specific error.
Let's write our expectations down in the document.
It is not an internal server error if the client has provided an invalid certificate, that's a user data error. It's an internal server error if the client's certificate crashes the BMC or PHYP.
yes. we will map to appropriate HTTP error codes.
What are the appropriate error codes for the PLDM errors?

Andrew, What Ravi wanted to say that if there is Invalid CSR data, could be 
Invalid expiry Date,
Invalid start Date.
Invalid Key length,
Invalid Type(other then PEM/DER)

they all would be mapped to 4XX, Other then user data would be mapped to 5XX(BMC/PHYP/VMI internal error).
Right, but we should be documenting what conditions map to what errors so people reading this document will know how to consume the interface.

In https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/23417/7/designs/management-console/file_management.md#87 it is /ibm/v1/host/partitions/ for the partitions? Why VMInterface here? Can the capitalization be the same for everythign under /ibm/v1/?

Gunnar 
we used VMI in capital letters as its abbreviation Virualization management interface
I observed same way followed in redfish schemas as well for DHCP
please refer https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/EthernetInterface.v1_5_1.json

Redfish has several Certificate schemas, could we use them ?
https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/schema_index
Could this VMI / hypervisor be modeled as like a ComputerSystem?

Gunnar

we cant use redfish certificate schema 
SignCSR() just pass through interface which accepts CSR string,forwards to VMI(CA) to get it signed and return signed certificate and Root CA certificate.
This requirement is out of scope for existing certificate service
We will come up with a schema for VMI Certificate service.
Comment on PS14 still needs to be addressed
done.going to use pldm file IO approach
Comment on PS14 still needs to be addressed
Comment on PS14 still needs to be addressed.
I think we need to make this more concrete, see comments on PS14.

The URI can be modified as
/ibm/vi/Host/VMICertificate/SignCSR

PS : The VMI network has modified now to follow the EthernetInterface schema. So the URI is now modified as /ibm/v1/Host/VMINetworkInterfaces/eth0. So there is no need for REST path as /ibm/v1/VMInterface

Don't need Content-Type for a GET. 
In requests, (such as POST or PUT), the client tells the server what type of data is actually sent.

management ?
Would recommend you run this through a grammar/spell checker like grammarly.com or microsoft office

Why can't we use Redfish Certificates for this? 
And Why can't we use the existing BMC certificate management infrastructure but not send the raw password via PLDM ?

As mentioned, our requirement is to get signed certificate for management console by VMI, we don't have
redfish interface for the same. 
VMI can't use BMC's authentication mechanism without sending password provided by user for validation
PLDM shall use the file IP approach for certificate exchange

space after the .
It is ? It's?
Please add some sub heading for this as - Get the root certificate

- Is this supposed to a blocking API.

- If yes, the doc doesn't capture how the blocking nature of the API would be designed/implemented.

- In case of multiple HMCs simultaneously issuing this request, what is the behavior?

yes.this blocking api
please refer Impacts section 4th point, line no.211

The impacts section doesn't make it clear as to how the client would be "blocked".

Also I had another question above. In general this document probably needs more details, wherever applicable, for the multi-HMC scenarios.
How will this work for multiple outstanding CSRs?

file names will be appended with random number.
each request has its own set of files.
We shouldn't be doing this. A D-Bus API is the long term solution. For the short term - to make this work for a single HMC, pls revert this back the filenames you had before.
Another problem with this approach is - error paths, like an invalid CSR is hard to handle.
Seems more description is needed, how to handle it through D-bus approach, where bmcweb will create the files and share the FD over D-bus and have the error code enum to show the success/failures.
yeah.adding a dbus method to handle errors.
Since this point is a contradiction to the previous one, you should make this more clear. For eg that this is a staging plan, etc.
I would say we should stick to the sharing the file descriptor approach, staging is internal to IBM not for this doc perspective.
Can you add the details of the D-Bus interface?

=> Once PLDM on BMC will get the certficate as a response of signCSR , it updates the Dbus object property named certificate and update the status property to complete in the Dbus object.


Details are missing.

Please try to expand the design flow(line no:78) to include this design.

=> Bmcweb creates the Dbus Object for each sign CSR request
=> pldm would be monitoring the Dbus object for interface added signal.
=> After getting the interface added signal pldm(BMC) will fetch the CSR from the dbus object itself and send it to PHYP.
=> Once PLDM on BMC will get the certficate as a response of signCSR , it updates the Dbus object property named certificate and update the status property to complete in the Dbus object.
=> bmcweb will be monitoring the status property to send the response to the client... (edited)
Updated details, above diagram is high level flow diagram.
D-Bus, is the right way to spell.
